today we're going to talk about dealing
with currency in Myanmar and me and more
there are two types of currency one is
the Burmese chat the other is the
American dollar you can use either one
the Burmese consider the chat kind of
equivalent to the dollar or the Burmese
scrutinising when it comes to the US
dollars yes they are highly scrutinizing
dollars which are crisp clean
unblemished on torn unworn just the
nicest you possibly can get the Burmese
will reject your dollar if it doesn't
meet their standard or seems
questionable
to show you proof here's some of my
dollars that got rejected first it's
worn it's been creased and you can see
the fade so this got rejected notice
here it's marked it's definitely
rejected the next one is this twenty
dollar bill you see the little ink it's
a little worn too my advice is to go to
your local bank and see how many
unblemished bills you can possibly get
from them I would also bring extra money
or backup money just in the case those
bills are rejected and where can you
exchange your money I exchanged mine at
the airport I kind of followed the other
tourists and they all congregated at one
money exchange place that place actually
had really good grades another good
place to exchange your money is your
hotel or guest house the big question
that everyone has is are there ATMs in
Myanmar and the good news is yes so far
were in Yangon I've seen four ATMs one
traveler Achmed said he saw ATMs in
yung-shiu and while I wouldn't rely on
ATMs to get my money exchanged Paymar
offers more options than they did in the
years past now things to watch out when
you receive Burmese chai you notice here
you know what that is it's a tear tape
together by electrical tape and this is
what they passed some vendor passed off
to me and I didn't see it I didn't know
so I just accepted it and now I can't
use it anywhere thank God it's like a
500 bill because that's only like maybe
50 cents if it were like 5000 shot and
that was like $5 I'd be pretty pissed
torn bills and burnt bills
once you receive it you're going to have
a hard time getting rid of it sometimes
the vendors the guest houses the market
people or the shop owners they will try
to give you the torn bills simply
because you're a traveler you're a
tourist and you wouldn't know the
difference if you don't look at the
change that you've been given you can
easily accept that bill
whenever you get change check your
currency you get a bill like this that's

so what do you do if you receive a torn

and to ask the vendor if he can exchange

they'll understand what you're talking
